description: Originated in Jamaican English or African American Vernacular English, probably originally a clipping of disrespect or disparage.

entries.meaning: (slang) An insult or put-down; an expression of disrespect.

verbs.description: diss (third-person singular simple present disses, present participle dissing, simple past and past participle dissed)

entries.meaning: (Canada, US, Britain, slang) To put (someone) down, or show disrespect by the use of insulting language or dismissive behaviour.
examples: When a journalistic rival tries to "dis" youAnd to prejudice you in the public's eyes.Don't stigmatise his charges as a "tissueOf palpable, unmitigated lies."

entries.meaning: Ampelodesmos mauritanicus syn. Ampelodesmos tenax, a reedy grass used for cordage.
